member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.VertexDrawer
member.summary: Draws a vertex as a circle, disk, or sphere.
member.remarks:
This class draws a vertex as a circle, disk, or sphere centered on the vertex's . It is typically used with , which takes the into account when edges are drawn, although other edge drawers can be used as well.
This class works in conjunction with to draw vertices as either selected or unselected. If a vertex has been marked as selected by , it is drawn using . Otherwise, is used. Set the property to false to force all vertices to be drawn as unselected.
If this class is used by a graph drawer other than , all vertices are drawn as unselected.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IVertexDrawer
member.summary: Supports vertex drawing.
member.remarks:
A class that implements this interface is responsible for drawing the vertices of a graph.
An implementation is typically meant to be used with a corresponding implementation of the interface, although this isn't a requirement. A vertex drawer can determine the type of the edge drawer in use by looking at the property on the object passed to . If the edge drawer is not of the expected corresponding type, the vertex drawer should revert to some sensible, if not ideal, default behavior.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.ILayout
member.summary: Supports laying out a graph within a rectangle.
member.remarks:
A class that implements this interface is responsible for laying out a graph within a specified rectangle by setting the property on all of the graph's vertices, and optionally adding geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges. Laying out a graph is the first step in drawing it.
If the layout is slow, you should consider implementing the interface instead.

member.summary: Lays out a graph.
member.param: Graph to lay out.
Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph.
member.remarks: This method lays out the graph by setting the property on all of the graph's vertices, and optionally adding geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.ILayout.TransformLayout(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext)
member.summary: Transforms a graph's current layout.
member.param: Graph whose layout needs to be transformed.
object that was passed to the most recent call to .
Provides access to the new graph rectangle.
member.remarks: After a graph has been laid out by , this method can be used to transform the graph's layout from one rectangle to another. contains the original graph rectangle, and contains the new graph rectangle. The implementation should transform all the graph's vertex locations from the original rectangle to the new one. If added geometry metadata to the graph, the implementation should also transform that metadata.

member.summary: Processes a vertex that was moved after the graph was laid out.
member.param: The vertex that was moved.
member.remarks: An application may allow the user to move a vertex after the graph has been laid out by . This method is called after the application has changed the property on . If added geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges, should modify the metadata if necessary.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.ILayout.Margin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin to subtract from each edge of the graph rectangle before laying out the graph.
member.value: The margin to subtract from each edge. Must be greater than or equal to zero. The units are determined by the object used to draw the graph. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: If the graph rectangle passed to is {L=0, T=0, R=50, B=30} and the is 5, for example, then the graph is laid out within the rectangle {L=5, T=5, R=45, B=25}.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.ILayout.LayoutRequired

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.GraphDrawerBase
member.summary: Base class for graph drawers.
member.remarks: This abstract class can serve as a base class for implementations. Its implementations of the public methods provide error checking but usually defer the actual work to protected abstract methods.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IGraphDrawer
member.summary: Supports graph drawing.
member.remarks:
A class that implements this interface is responsible for drawing a graph.
The implementation will typically draw a graph by laying it out via the method on the object, drawing the edges via repeated calls to the method on the object, and drawing the vertices via repeated calls to the method on the object. The order is important: The edges and vertices can't be drawn before sets the property on the vertices, and the vertices are drawn after the edges so that the vertices cover the ends of the edges.
The interface does not define any draw methods, because the arguments passed to such methods vary with the implementation. The implementation might draw on a or a object, for example. It's conceivable that the graph drawer might not even draw directly on a visible surface; an implementation might "draw" to a VML file, for example.
If your graph drawer uses an asynchronous layout, you should consider implementing the interface instead.

member.overloads: Gets the vertex containing a specified point.

This method looks for a vertex that contains . If there is such a vertex, the vertex is stored at and true is returned. Otherwise, is set to null and false is returned.
The graph should be drawn before this method is used. If the graph hasn't been drawn, the return value is unpredictable.
The method on the object is used to determine which vertex, if any, contains the point.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.EdgeDrawer
member.summary: Draws an edge as a simple line.
member.remarks:
This class draws an edge as a simple line connecting the edge's vertices. It is meant to be used with , whose is taken into account when the edge is drawn. If a vertex drawer other than is used, the edge is drawn between the centers of the edge's vertices.
This class works in conjunction with to draw edges as either selected or unselected. If an edge has been marked as selected by , it is drawn using and . Otherwise, and are used. Set the property to false to force all edges to be drawn as unselected.
If this class is used by a graph drawer other than , all edges are drawn as unselected.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.EdgeDrawerBase
member.summary: Base class for edge drawers.
member.remarks: This abstract class can serve as a base class for implementations. Its implementations of the public methods provide error checking but defer the actual work to protected abstract methods.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IEdgeDrawer
member.summary: Supports edge drawing.
member.remarks:
A class that implements this interface is responsible for drawing the edges of a graph.
An implementation is typically meant to be used with a corresponding implementation of the interface, although this isn't a requirement. An edge drawer can determine the type of the vertex drawer in use by looking at the property on the object passed to . If the vertex drawer is not of the expected corresponding type, the edge drawer should revert to some sensible, if not ideal, default behavior.

Provides access to objects needed for drawing operations.
member.remarks: This method gets called repeatedly while a graph is being drawn, once for each of the graph's edges. The property on all of the graph's vertices is set by ILayout. before this method is called.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IEdgeDrawer.RedrawRequired
member.summary: Occurs when a change occurs that requires a graph redraw.
member.remarks:
The implementation must fire this event when a change is made to the object that might affect the appearance of the graph.
The object owner should handle the event by redrawing the graph. The graph does not need to be laid out again.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IEdgeDrawer.LayoutRequired
member.summary: Occurs when a change occurs that requires the graph to be laid out again.
member.remarks:
The implementation must fire this event when a change is made to the object that might affect the layout of the graph.
The object owner should lay out the graph and redraw it in response to the event.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncGraphDrawer
member.summary: Supports graph drawing using an event-based asynchronous pattern.
member.remarks:
A class that implements this interface is responsible for drawing a graph in either a synchronous or asynchronous manner.
Neither this interface nor its base interface define any Draw methods, because the arguments passed to such methods vary with the implementation. The implementation might draw on a or a object, for example. It's conceivable that the graph drawer might not even draw directly on a visible surface; an implementation might "draw" to a VML file, for example.
The implemention must define at least one synchronouos Draw method, along with an asynchronous DrawAsync counterpart that follows the guidelines outlined in the article "Multithreaded Programming with the Event-based Asynchronous Pattern" in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide. The DrawAsync method starts the drawing on a worker thread and returns immediately. The event may fire repeatedly while the drawing is occurring. The event fires when the drawing is complete, an error occurs, or the drawing is cancelled. cancels the drawing.

member.overloads: Gets the vertex containing a specified point.
member.summary: Gets the vertex containing a specified .
member.param: Point to get a vertex for.

member.returns: true if a vertex containing the point was found, false if not.
member.remarks:
This method looks for a vertex that contains . If there is such a vertex, the vertex is stored at and true is returned. Otherwise, is set to null and false is returned.
The graph should be drawn before this method is used. If the graph hasn't been drawn, the return value is unpredictable.
The method on the object is used to determine which vertex, if any, contains the point.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncGraphDrawer.LayoutRequired
member.summary: Occurs when a change occurs that requires the graph to be laid out again.
member.remarks:
The implementation must fire this event when any change is made to the object that might affect the layout of the graph, such as a vertex being added to the graph.
The owner should lay out the graph and redraw it in response to the event.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncGraphDrawer.RedrawRequired
member.summary: Occurs when a change occurs that requires a graph redraw.
member.remarks:
The implementation fires this event when any change is made to the object that might affect the appearance of the graph. It does not fire when a graph is being drawn asynchronously and the drawing completes one iteration.
The object owner should handle the event by redrawing the graph. The graph does not need to be laid out again.

member.summary: Occurs when a drawing started by a DrawAsync method completes one iteration.
member.remarks:
If the uses an iterative algorithm in which the graph is laid out and drawn multiple times before it reaches its final layout, this event fires after each iteration is completed.
The event fires on the thread on which the DrawAsync method was called.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.AsyncGraphDrawer.DrawAsyncCompleted
member.summary: Occurs when a drawing started by a DrawAsync method completes, is cancelled, or ends with an error.
member.remarks:
The event fires on the thread on which the DrawAsync method was called.
If the drawing was cancelled by , the AsyncCompletedEventArgs. property is set to true. If an exception is thrown during drawing, the AsyncCompletedEventArgs. property is set to the exception. If you want to determine whether the drawing successfully completed, you must check both of these properties.
Do not check for errors by putting a try/catch block around the DrawAsync call. Check the AsyncCompletedEventArgs. property instead.

member.summary: Supports laying out a graph within a rectangle using an event-based asynchronous pattern.
member.remarks:
This interface adds asynchronous semantics to the base interface. A class that implements this interface is responsible for laying out a graph within a specified rectangle by setting the property on all of the graph's vertices in either a synchronous or asynchronous manner, depending on whether or is called. It may also add geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges.
The asynchronous semantics follow the guidelines outlined in the article "Multithreaded Programming with the Event-based Asynchronous Pattern" in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide. starts the layout on a worker thread and returns immediately. The event may fire repeatedly while the layout is occurring. The event fires when the layout is complete, an error occurs, or the layout is cancelled. cancels the layout.

member.summary: Lays out a graph asynchronously.
member.param: Graph to lay out.
Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph.
member.remarks:
This method asynchronously lays out the graph . It returns immediately. A worker thread sets the property on all of the graph's vertices, and optionally adds geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges.
The event may fire repeatedly while the layout is occurring. The event fires when the layout is complete, an error occurs, or the layout is cancelled. cancels the layout.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncLayout.LayOutGraphAsyncCancel
member.summary: Cancels the layout started by .
member.remarks:
The layout may or may not cancel, but the event is guaranteed to fire. The object passed to the event handler contains a property that indicates whether the cancellation occurred.
If a layout is not in progress, this method does nothing.

member.value: true if an asynchronous operation is in progress.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncLayout.LayOutGraphIterationCompleted
member.summary: Occurs when a layout started by completes one iteration.
member.remarks:
If the implementation uses an iterative layout algorithm, it should fire this event after each iteration. The event handler may draw the intermediate graph using the property on all of the graph's vertices.
The event fires on the thread on which was called. Although the property is not required to be thread-safe, it is safe to read the property during the event because the implementation's worker thread blocks until the event handler returns.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncLayout.LayOutGraphCompleted
member.summary: Occurs when a layout started by completes, is cancelled, or ends with an error.
member.remarks: The event fires on the thread on which was called.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.IAsyncLayout.LayoutRequired
member.summary: Occurs when a change occurs that requires the graph to be laid out again.
member.remarks:
The implementation must fire this event when any change is made to the object that might affect the layout of the graph, such as a property change that affects the layout algorithm.
The owner should lay out the graph and redraw it in response to the event.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.AsyncLayoutBase.FireLayOutGraphIterationCompleted
member.summary: Fires the event if appropriate.
member.remarks:
This method should be called from after each layout iteration. It synchronously fires the event on the thread from which was called.
Note that the method can't be used to report completion of an iteration. That's because fires a event asynchronously, meaning that the worker thread gets back to work immediately without waiting for the event handler to return. Because the worker thread is modifying the Location properties of all the graph's vertices, which is exactly what the event handler wants to read, the vertex locations would not be in a stable state for reading. Using SynchronizationContext to synchronously Send an event solves this problem, because the worker thread can't get back to work until the event handler returns.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.SugiyamaLayout
member.summary: Lays out a graph using the Sugiyama layered layout scheme.
member.remarks:
This layout uses an algorithm based on Sugiyama's layered layout scheme. It is implemented with the Microsoft Research GLEE (Graph Layout Execution Engine) library. GLEE was developed by Lev Nachmanson of Microsoft Research and was available on the Microsoft Research download site as of January 2007.
The Microsoft.GLEE.dll assembly must be included in the build that uses this class.
and should be used to draw the graph after it is laid out.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.SugiyamaLayout.TransformLayoutCore(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix)
member.summary: Transforms a graph's current layout.
member.param: Graph whose layout needs to be transformed.
object that was passed to the most recent call to .
Provides access to objects needed to transform the graph's layout.
Matrix that can be used to transform points from the original graph rectangle to the new graph rectangle.
member.remarks:
After a graph has been laid out by , this method may get called to transform the graph's layout from one rectangle to another. contains the original graph rectangle, and contains the new graph rectangle. The base-class implementation transforms all the graph's vertex locations from the original rectangle to the new one. If the derived implementation added geometry metadata to the graph, the derived class should override this method, transform the geometry metadata, and call the base-class implementation to transform the graph's vertex locations.
The arguments have already been checked for validity.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ArgumentChecker
member.summary: Contains methods that check method arguments and property values.
member.remarks:
This can be used by a class that wants to check values passed to its property setters and arguments passed to its methods. The CheckXXX() methods in this class throw an exception if a parameter value or method argument is invalid.
This class is marked internal to avoid compiler error CS0433 ("The type ... exists in both ...") when an executable references two or more assemblies that use this class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout
member.summary: Lays out a graph using the Fruchterman-Reingold layout.
member.remarks:
For details on the layout algorithm, see http://www.cs.ubc.ca/rr/proceedings/spe91-95/spe/vol21/issue11/spe060tf.pdf.
and can be used to draw the graph after it is laid out.

members.member: Number of iterations to run the algorithm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the FruchtermanReingoldLayout class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.LayOutGraphCore(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,System.ComponentModel.BackgroundWorker)
member.summary: Lays out a graph synchronously or asynchronously.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.
Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph. The is guaranteed to have non-zero width and height.
whose worker thread called this method if the graph is being laid out asynchronously, or null if the graph is being laid out synchronously.
member.returns: true if the layout was successfully completed, false if the layout was cancelled. The layout can be cancelled only if the graph is being laid out asynchronously.
member.remarks:
This method lays out the graph either synchronously (if is null) or asynchronously (if ( is not null) by setting the the property on all of the graph's vertices and optionally adding geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges.
In the asynchronous case, the property on the object should be checked before each layout iteration. If it's true, the method should immediately return false. Also, should be called after each iteration.
The arguments have already been checked for validity.

member.summary: Stores required metadata on the graph's vertices before the layout begins.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.RemoveMetadata(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph)
member.summary: Removes metadata from the graph's vertices after the layout is complete.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.CalculateRepulsiveForces(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,System.Single)
member.summary: Calculates the repulsive forces between the vertices.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.
The "k" constant in the Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm.
member.remarks: The results are stored in the FruchtermanReingoldVertexInfo object stored in each vertex's Tag.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.CalculateAttractiveForces(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,System.Single)
member.summary: Calculates the attractive forces between the vertices.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.
The "k" constant in the Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm.
member.remarks: The results are added to the existing FruchtermanReingoldVertexInfo object stored in each vertex's Tag.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.FruchtermanReingoldLayout.SetVertexLocations(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the location of each vertex.
member.param: Graph to lay out. The graph is guaranteed to have at least one vertex.
Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph. The is guaranteed to have non-zero width and height.
Current temperature. Must be greater than zero.
member.remarks: This method is called at the end of each layout iteration. For each vertex, it modifies the vertex's location within an unbounded rectangle based on the repulsive and attractive forces that have been calculated for the vertex, transforms that unbounded location to a point within the bounded graph rectangle, and sets the vertex's property to that bounded point.

member.param: Rectangle to convert.
Width of the pen that will be used to draw the rectangle.
member.returns: Converted rectangle.
member.remarks:
This method converts a floating-point RectangleF to an integer Rectangle, compensating for some GDI oddities in the process.
If precise rectangle drawing is required, the caller should convert all RectangleF objects to Rectangles using this method, then use the Graphics.DrawRectangle(Pen, Rectangle) method to draw them. The floating-point version of Graphics.DrawRectangle() should not be used.

member.summary: Lays out a graph by placing all vertices on a grid.

This layout places all vertices on a simple grid.
If you want the vertices to be placed in a certain order, set the property to an object that will sort them.
and can be used to draw the graph after it is laid out.

Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph. The is guaranteed to have non-zero width and height.
whose worker thread called this method if the graph is being laid out asynchronously, or null if the graph is being laid out synchronously.
member.returns: true if the layout was successfully completed, false if the layout was cancelled. The layout can be cancelled only if the graph is being laid out asynchronously.
member.remarks:
This method lays out the graph either synchronously (if is null) or asynchronously (if ( is not null) by setting the the property on all of the graph's vertices and optionally adding geometry metadata to the graph, vertices, or edges.
In the asynchronous case, the property on the object should be checked before each layout iteration. If it's true, the method should immediately return false. Also, should be called after each iteration.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.GridLayout.GetRowsAndColumns(Microsoft.Chung.Core.IGraph,Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.LayoutContext,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Gets the number of rows and columns to use in the grid.
member.param: Graph to lay out.
Provides access to objects needed to lay out the graph.

Where the number of grid rows gets stored. Because the first row of vertices is drawn on the first horizontal grid line and not on the top edge of the rectangle, the number of vertices to draw per column is minus one.

Where the number of grid columns gets stored. Because the first column of vertices is drawn on the first vertical grid line and not on the left edge of the rectangle, the number of vertices to draw per row is minus one.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Chung.Visualization.SugiyamaVertexDrawer
member.summary: Draws a vertex as a circle, disk, or sphere, in conjunction with and .
member.remarks:
This class draws vertices that have been laid out by as circles, disks, or spheres centered on each vertex's . It is meant for use with .
This class works in conjunction with to draw vertices as either selected or unselected. If a vertex has been marked as selected by , it is drawn using . Otherwise, is used. Set the property to false to force all vertices to be drawn as unselected.
If this class is used by a graph drawer other than , all vertices are drawn as unselected.

members.member: Minimum radius to use.

member.summary: Gets the actual radius to use for a vertex.
member.param: The vertex to get the actual radius for.
member.returns: The actual radius to use.
member.remarks: If the parent graph of contains a metadata value for the radius computed by , the computed radius is returned. Otherwise, the base-class method is called.
